University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Signal

Consumer confidence and expectations as a forward demand indicator.

As of 2025-11-29

Gemini Summary

The market is characterized by pervasive bearish sentiment, primarily driven by a significant decline in consumer confidence. The University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index (UMCSENT) registered a stark 53.6 as of October 31, 2025, marking a severe -23.97% year-over-year drop and a -13.13% decline over the last three months. This persistent "Bearish" signal, present since August 2024, suggests elevated risk aversion and potential headwinds for consumer-driven economic growth and, by extension, equities. While specific data for bonds, precious, and industrial metals is absent, this bearish consumer outlook typically leads to a flight to safety, supporting bonds and potentially gold, while industrial metals face demand-side pressures due to anticipated weaker demand. Systemic financial stress, as measured by the Financial Stress Composite, remains a critical unobserved factor without current readings.

Technical Summary: From a sentiment perspective, the technical outlook is distinctly bearish. The UMCSENT index exhibits a clear downtrend, with its `Level_z` consistently in negative territory, currently at -1.018 as of October 2025. This sustained negative momentum, evident across year-over-year and three-month changes, points to deeply entrenched pessimism that could exert continued downward pressure on risk assets, particularly equities.

References:

  • University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index (UMCSENT) data table: Latest date 2025-10-31. This dataset is particularly relevant for current market sentiment and economic outlook.
  • Financial Stress Composite Methodology document: Outlines a critical framework for assessing systemic risk using STLFSI4, HY_OAS, and T10Y2Y. Latest date implies 2025.
Publicly available data that would enhance this analysis includes current readings for the Financial Stress Composite components (STLFSI4, HY_OAS, T10Y2Y) and its overall signal, major equity indices (e.g., S&P 500 performance), bond yields (e.g., US 10-year Treasury), commodity prices (e.g., Gold, Copper), and volatility indicators (e.g., VIX).
